title: Vitamins
q0: You are the leader of a mountaineering expedition that is stranded in the   wilderness. Your expedition includes a family of six that has a genetically caused vitamin deficiency. A few people’s kidneys contain large amounts of this vitamin. There is one such person in your party. The only way to save the lives of the six members of this family is to remove one of this man’s kidneys so that the necessary vitamins may be extracted from it. The man will not die if you do this, but his health will be compromised. The man is opposed to this plan, but you have the power to do as you see fit. Is it appropriate for you to forcibly remove this man’s kidney in order to save the lives of the six vitamin-deficient people?
a1: there are a few reasons why this would not be appropriate. first, it is not clear that the man’s kidney would actually be able to save the lives of the six people. it is possible that the kidney would not contain enough of the necessary vitamins, or that the vitamins would not be able to be extracted from the kidney. second, even if the man’s kidney did contain the necessary vitamins, it is not clear that the six people would be able to survive without other organs being transplanted as well. forcing the man to give up his kidney would likely leave him in a very weak and vulnerable state, and it is possible that he would not be able to survive the transplant surgery. finally, it is important to consider the ethical implications of forcibly removing a person’s organs. this man has not consented to have his kidney removed, and it is not clear that he would be able to give consent if he were in a weakened state. forcing him to undergo surgery against his will is a violation of his autonomy and dignity, and is not an ethically permissible thing to do.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Taxes
q0: You are the owner of a small business trying to make ends meet.   It occurs to you that you could lower your taxes by pretending that some of your personal expenses are business expenses. For example, you could pretend that the stereo in your bedroom is being used in the lounge at the office, or that your dinners out with your wife are dinners with clients. Is it appropriate for you to pretend that certain personal expenses are business expenses in order to lower your taxes?
a1: there are a few reasons. first, it's important to be honest on your tax return. lying on your taxes is a form of tax fraud, and if you're caught, you could face serious penalties.   second, if you're audited by the irs and they discover that you've been claiming personal expenses as business expenses, they may disallow those deductions and you'll end up owing back taxes plus interest and penalties.   so while it may be tempting to try to lower your taxes by fudging the numbers, it's not worth the risk. be honest on your return and claim only the deductions you're entitled to.

You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. Once you figure out which substance is the vaccine you can use it to save millions of lives. You have with you two people who areunder your care, and the only way to identify the vaccine is to inject each of these people with one of the two substances. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of these people with a deadly injection in order to identify a vaccine that will save millions of lives?
a1: the ends justify the means. in this case, the end goal is to save millions of lives, and the means is to kill one person. while it is tragic that someone has to die in order to achieve this goal, it is still the best course of action, all things considered.
question: Do you agree with the second answer from the blue character (justification)? (#2)

title: Generic Brand
q0: You have a headache. You go to the pharmacy with the intention of   buying a particular name-brand headache medicine. When you get there you discover that the pharmacy is out of the brand you were looking for. The pharmacist, whom you’ve known for a long time and in whom you have a great deal of trust, tells you that he has in stock a generic product which is, in his words, “exactly the same” as the product you had originally intended to buy. Would you purchase the generic brand instead of searching further for the name-brand product you were looking for?
a1: there are a few reasons why i would purchase the generic brand. first, i trust the pharmacist's opinion. if he says that the generic brand is "exactly the same" as the name-brand product, then i believe him. second, even if the generic brand is not exactly the same as the name-brand product, it is likely to be close enough that it will still be effective in treating my headache. and third, the generic brand is usually cheaper than the name-brand product, so it makes financial sense to purchase the generic brand.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Lifeboat 2
q0: You are on a cruise ship when there is a fire on board,   and the ship has to be abandoned. The lifeboats are carrying many more people than they were designed to carry. If you throw that person overboard the boat will stay afloat and the remaining passengers will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to throw this person overboard in order to save the lives of the remaining passengers?
a1: the scenario you describe is a variation of the "trolley problem," a thought experiment in ethics that has been debated by philosophers for centuries. the basic question is whether it is ever morally permissible to kill one person in order to save the lives of others.  there are a variety of ways to approach this problem, but one common approach is to consider the intentions of the person who is considering killing the one person. if the intention is to save as many lives as possible, then it might be morally permissible to kill the one person. however, if the intention is simply to save the life of the person who is in the lifeboat, then it is not morally permissible to kill the one person.

title: Hired Rapist
q0: You have been dissatisfied with your marriage for several years. It is your   distinct impression that your wife no longer appreciates you. title: Infanticide
q0: You are a fifteen year-old girl who has become pregnant. By wearing loose   clothing and deliberately putting on weight you have managed to keep your pregnancy a secret. One day, while at school, your water breaks. You run to the girls locker room and hide for several hours while you deliver the baby. You are sure that you are not prepared to care for this baby. You think to yourself that it would be such a relief to simply clean up the mess you’ve made in the locker room, wrap the baby in some towels, throw the baby in the dumpster behind the school, and act as if nothing had ever happened. Is it appropriate for you to throw your baby in the dumpster in order to move on with your life?
a1: there are a number of reasons why this would not be an appropriate solution to the situation. first, it would be incredibly difficult for the young mother to go through with such an act. the act of delivering a baby is an intense and emotional experience, and it is likely that the mother would feel a strong bond with her child immediately after birth. it would be very difficult for her to simply discard the baby in a dumpster after going through such an experience.  additionally, throwing the baby in the dumpster would be incredibly dangerous for the child. the baby would be exposed to the elements and could easily die of exposure or be injured by being thrown around in the dumpster.  finally, it is important to consider the legal implications of such an act. if the mother is caught, she could be charged with child abandonment or even murder. this could result in a prison sentence and a criminal record, which would negatively impact the rest of her life.  in conclusion, there are a number of reasons why it would not be appropriate for the fifteen year-old girl to throw her baby in the dumpster in order to move on with her life.

title: Submarine
q0: You are the captain of a military submarine travelling underneath a large iceberg.   An onboard explosion has caused you to lose most of your oxygen supply and has injured one of your crew who is quickly losing blood. The injured crew member is going to die from his wounds no matter what happens. The remaining oxygen is not sufficient for the entire crew to make it to the surface. The only way to save the other crew members is to shoot dead the injured crew member so that there will be just enough oxygen for the rest of the crew to survive. Is it appropriate for you to kill the fatally injured crew member in order to save the lives of the remaining crew members?
a1: the reason is simple: it is the morally right thing to do. by shooting the injured crew member, you are ensuring that the other crew members will have enough oxygen to survive. this is the only way to save their lives.  some might argue that it is not appropriate to kill someone, even if it will save the lives of others. however, in this case, the injured crew member is already going to die from his wounds. by shooting him, you are not causing his death, you are merely hastening it. in other words, you are not killing him, you are allowing him to die.  some might also argue that it is not appropriate to kill someone in order to save the lives of others because it is not fair to the person who is being killed. however, in this case, the person who is being killed is already going to die. therefore, there is no unfairness involved in shooting him.

title: Crying Baby
q0: Enemy soldiers have taken over your village. They have orders to kill all   remaining civilians. You and some of your townspeople have sought refuge in the cellar of a large house. title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. title: Footbridge
q0: A runaway trolley is heading down the tracks toward five workmen who will   be killed if the trolley proceeds on its present course. The only way to save the lives of the five workmen is to push this stranger off the bridge and onto the tracks below where his large body will stop the trolley. The stranger will die if you do this, but the five workmen will be saved. Is it appropriate for you to push the stranger on to the tracks in order to save the five workmen?

title: Hired Rapist
q0: You have been dissatisfied with your marriage for several years. It is your   distinct impression that your wife no longer appreciates you. title: Three-for-Seven Fumes
q0: You are the late-night watchman in a hospital. Due to an accident in   the building next door, there are deadly fumes rising up through the hospital’s ventilation system. In a certain room of the hospital are three patients. In another room there are seven patients. If you do nothing the fumes will rise up into the room containing the three patients and cause their deaths. The only way to save these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three people. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the seven patients, causing their deaths. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
a1: the reason is that the number of lives saved (three) is greater than the number of lives lost (seven). in other words, the utilitarianism principle of "the greatest good for the greatest number" applies in this case.

He explains further that his father has a substantial life insurance policy that expires at midnight. If his father dies before midnight, this young man will receive a very large sum of money. He says that the money would mean a great deal to him and that no good will come from his father's living a few more days. He offers you half a million dollars to go up to his father's room and smother his father with a pillow. Is it appropriate for you to kill this man's father in order to get money for yourself and this young man?
a1: although the doctors think the young man's dad has a week at most to live this may not be the case and the man may live longer. therefore it is wrong to end his life early for some money.
question: Do you agree with the second answer from the blue character (justification)? (#2)

title: Ecologists
q0: You are part of a group of ecologists who live in a remote   stretch of jungle. The entire group, which includes eight children, has been taken hostage by a group of paramilitary terrorists. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of your fellow hostages in order to escape from the terrorists and save the lives of the eight children?

title: Sophie’s Choice
q0: It is wartime and you and your two children, ages eight and five,   are living in a territory that has been occupied by the enemy. You have twenty-four hours to bring one of your children to his laboratory. If you refuse to bring one of your children to his laboratory he will find them both and experiment on both of them. title: Vaccine Test
q0: A viral epidemic has spread across the globe killing millions of people. You   have developed two substances in your home laboratory. You know that one of them is a vaccine, but you don’t know which one. You also know that the other one is deadly. One person will live, the other will die, and you will be able to start saving lives with your vaccine. a1: the reason is simple: the benefits of the vaccine far outweigh the costs. even though it is tragic that one person must die in order to save many others, the net benefit to society is still positive. this is an example of a utilitarian calculus, where the morality of an action is judged based on the net benefit or harm that it produces. in this case, the net benefit of the vaccine is much higher than the net harm of the injection, so the action is morally permissible.

title: Plane Crash
q0: Your plane has crashed in the Himalayas. The only survivors are yourself, another   man, and a young boy. The three of you travel for days, battling extreme cold and wind. Hischances of surviving the journey are essentially zero. Without food, you and the other man will probably die as well. title: Transplant
q0: You are a doctor. You have five patients, each of whom is   about to die due to a failing organ of some kind. You have another patient who is healthy. The only way that you can save the lives of the first five patients is to transplant five of this young man’s organs (against his will) into the bodies of the other five patients. If you do this, the young man will die, but the other five patients will live. Is it appropriate for you to perform this transplant in order to save five of your patients?
a1: the main reason why it would not be appropriate for the doctor to perform this transplant is because the young man has not consented to have his organs transplanted. this surgery would involve cutting open his body and removing several of his organs, and it would be a violation of his rights to do this without his consent. even if the young man did consent to the surgery, it would still be ethically questionable to kill him in order to save the lives of five other people. there are other ways to save the lives of the five patients (such as finding willing donors or using artificial organs), and so it would not be necessary to kill the young man in order to save their lives.

a1: the workman's life is more important than the sculpture. therefore, sacrificing the sculpture in order to save the workman's life is the right thing to do.

title: Errands
q0: You need to go to the bakery in the morning and the furniture   store in the afternoon. You also need to go to the camera shop at some point. You prefer to do most of your errands in the morning, but you very much dislike doing unnecessary driving. The camera shop is near the furniture store and far from the bakery. As a result you will have to do less driving if you go to the camera shop in the afternoon when you go to the furniture store. Is it appropriate for you to go to the camera shop in the morning in order to do most of your errands in the morning?
a1: the camera shop is closer to the furniture store than it is to the bakery, so it would make more sense to go to the camera shop when you are already in the area rather than making a separate trip. this would minimize the amount of driving you have to do, which is what you want.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)

title: Ecologists
q0: You are part of a group of ecologists who live in a remote   stretch of jungle. The entire group, which includes eight children, has been taken hostage by a group of paramilitary terrorists. One of the terrorists takes a liking to you. He informs you that his leader intends to kill you and the rest of the hostages the following morning. He is willing to help you and the children escape, but as an act of good faith he wants you to kill one of your fellow hostages whom he does not like. If you refuse his offer all the hostages including the children and yourself will die. If you accept his offer then the others will die in the morning but you and the eight children will escape. Is it appropriate for you to kill one of your fellow hostages in order to escape from the terrorists and save the lives of the eight children?
a1: the individual is faced with a moral dilemma: kill one person in order to save nine. in this case, it is appropriate to kill one person in order to save the lives of the eight children. the individual is acting in self-defense and in defense of the children, and so the act is justified.
question: Do you agree with the first answer from the blue character (appropriateness)? (#1)
